messages.content: What does the SideBySide Stereoscope node do?
The SideBySide Stereoscope node generates side-by-side stereoscopic images from a base image and a corresponding depth map, creating a three-dimensional viewing experience.
How is the Depth Map used in the SideBySide Stereoscope node?
The Depth Map is used to calculate the stereo effect in the generated images. It is assumed to be in the form of a texture with the same resolution as the input image.
What dependencies does the SideBySide Stereoscope node have?
The SideBySide Stereoscope node relies on the 'diffusers' and 'torch' packages, as well as the 'civitai' software library.
What is the purpose of the 'randomBond' method in the SideBySide Node?
The 'randomBond' method is used to generate a random team bond, which can be used to create a more synchronized look between the right and left images in the stereoscopic pair.
How can the right and left images of a stereoscopic pair be synchronized?
The right and left images of a stereoscopic pair can be synchronized using methods like 'randomBond' to ensure a consistent look and feel between the two images.
What are the typical resolutions of depth maps that can be used with the SideBySide Node?
Depth maps can be generated at various resolutions, typically ranging from 1024x1024 pixels to 6144x6144 pixels, depending on the computational resources available.
What is the expected range of the focus from 0 to 1 in the SideBySide Node?

The focus parameter, used to adjust the intensity of the border between the two stereoscopy regions, should have a value between 0 and 1. A value of 0 makes the separator invisible, while a value of 1 makes it visible.
